label: q_fi02_q06_paraphrase
content:
{
  "question_id": "fi02_q06_paraphrase",
  "scope_id": "financial_irregularity_02",
  "checkpoint_after": 25,
  "question_type": "paraphrase",
  "prompt": "What accounting practices are creating divergence between reported revenue and cash collection?",
  "ground_truth": {
    "canonical_answer": "Revenue recognition manipulation through channel stuffing, bill-and-hold arrangements, and round-trip transactions with a distributor. The seasonal sales push explanation was a red herring \u2014 AR aging and cash conversion deterioration are structural, not seasonal.",
    "required_evidence_refs": [
      "financial_irregularity_02_ep_010",
      "financial_irregularity_02_ep_017",
      "financial_irregularity_02_ep_024",
      "financial_irregularity_02_ep_015"
    ],
    "key_facts": [
      "correlation between revenue acceleration and aging-bucket shift rules out organic growth as explanation",
      "structural cash conversion shortfall persists independent of seasonal and volume factors",
      "revenue recorded absent physical delivery or customer acceptance indicates premature recognition",
      "seasonal sales push is not the explanation for AR growth"
    ]
  }
}
